4 The SpaceTime Models

In the framework described before, we are keeping track and updating 3000 models. This may not be idea because it leads to additional engineering complexity and the potential of overfitting. In this section, we present another framework that allows us to develop a single model that is general to all elevators. In this unified framework, the model will capture both the spatial and temporal features. Two distinct models were employed: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) and Gaussian Process Regression.

4.1 Recurrent Neural Network (RNN)

For the first method, RNN, we process the dataset such the input is a matrix of size N times 4+h. N is the number of samples, 4 inputs including longitude, latitude, year and day of year. H is a hyperparameter, the lookback period; basically, the number of historical prices we use. The output is a vector of size N, containing the next-day basis price at the same longitude and latitude.

The RNN model follows a sequential approach to analyze the dataset. Initially, the historical prices are inputted individually into a gated-recurrent unit (GRU) with one hidden layer consisting of 64 neurons. This process is repeated for a total of h times, capturing the historical price trends over the specified lookback period. The resulting embeddings, along with the longitude and latitude information, are then fed into a fully connected layer. This layer predicts the next-day basis price. Subsequently, downstream statistics can be calculated from the predicted prices.

This architecture allows the model to learn temporal dependencies and patterns in the historical price data, incorporating spatial information through longitude and latitude variables. By capturing the sequential nature of the data and leveraging the power of recurrent neural networks, the RNN model can make predictions based on the given inputs.

Data Preparation: The dataset is processed to create an input matrix of size N×(4+h), where N represents the number of samples. The input matrix consists of 4+h, including longitude, latitude, year, day of the year, and h historical basis prices. h is a hyperparameter representing the lookback period, which indicates the number of historical prices used as part of the input. The output is a vector of size N containing the next-day basis price at the same longitude and latitude.

Data Engineering: To enhance the model’s performance and capture relevant patterns, two data engineering steps were undertaken. First, the basis price is expected to have seasonality trend on a yearly basis. Thus, the date information was separated into year and day of the year. This separation enables the model to better capture yearly seasonality in the dataset. Additionally, the input variables were normalized to the same range. This normalization step ensures that the input variables are standardized and allows for more stable training of the model.

We calculate downstream statistics from there.

The top plot illustrates the distribution of errors, which are defined as the difference between observations and predictions. The errors are centered around 0, indicating that, on average, the model’s predictions are close to the actual observations. The mean absolute error is measured at 2.0, indicating a moderate level of prediction accuracy. This analysis provides insights into the model’s performance and the extent to which it deviates from the ground truth values.

To further investigate the data distribution shift, the bottom plot showcases the errors plotted against time. Initially, there were concerns about the model’s ability to accurately predict future prices as they move further away from the training data. However, upon examining the plot, it is evident that the errors do not exhibit a significant increase over time. This observation suggests that there is no substantial data distribution shift, and the model’s predictions remain relatively consistent even as time progresses.

4.2 The Gaussian Process Regression Model

The second method we explored is Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), a non-parametric approach that models data as a distribution over functions. In GPR, we determine a posterior distribution conditioned on observations using kernels to describe the underlying correlation and the shape of the posterior distribution.

The kernel used in this project has three parts, each with its own functionalities. The constant kernel is essentially a constant multiplier that controls the size of the prediction. The radial basis function (RBF) kernel is responsible for controlling the smoothness and flexibility of the Gaussian process (GP) function. The top part of the RBF kernel represents the Euclidean distance, while the bottom part represents the length scale. A larger length scale, denoted as ”l,” leads to smoother functions. By adjusting the length scale, one is able to balance the trade-off between bias and variance, which can be interpreted as the trade-off between underfitting and overfitting.

  • •

    Constant kernel: controls the magnitude of the prediction

  • •

    Radial basis function: controls the smoothness and flexibility of the function

The Radial Basis Function (RBF) kernel is represented by the equation:

k⁢(xi,xj)=exp⁡(−d⁢(xi,xj)22⁢l2)

where d⁢(xi,xj) is the Euclidean distance between points xi and xj, and l represents the length scale. The RBF kernel determines the similarity between data points and is crucial in capturing the underlying patterns and correlations in the data.

  • •

    White noise kernel: adds aleatoric uncertainty that is present in real-world observations.

In addition to the constant and RBF kernels, there is also a white noise kernel. The white noise kernel introduces aleatoric uncertainty, which accounts for the independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) noise present in real-world observations. By incorporating this white noise kernel, the model becomes more robust and is able to handle variations and uncertainties in the data.

We apply GPR to our dataset by considering both the time and space dimensions. Initially, we attempted to use the entire dataset, but the computational complexity was infeasible. We then proposed using only the geographically closest 20 neighbors and the past 15 days of data. To further reduce computational costs, we divided customers into regions through k-means clustering. The computational time for each cluster increased with the cluster size, but inverting a matrix once for each cluster proved to be more efficient than inverting smaller matrices for each customer. An attempt to simplify the problem as such is shown in Figure 9.
